title: Petitioners gathering signatures to repeal legal marijuana accused of misleading voters
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Signature gatherers for marijuana repeal accused of misleading voters with ambiguous petition descriptions.
Coalition for a Healthy Massachusetts denies allegations, attributing them to early success of the initiative.
State officials have received complaints and informed voters about stopping certification of their signatures.

title: Massachusetts state payroll hits $9B in 2025 — UMass system dominates
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Massachusetts state payroll reached $9.19 billion in 2025, down from $10.26 billion the previous year.
All 15 highest-paid state employees were from the UMass system, totaling $1.55 billion in payroll expenses.
UMass Men's Basketball Head Coach Frank Martin was the highest-paid state employee, earning $1,955,216.

title: Mass. State Police: 56 arrested in three-day child exploitation sweep
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Massachusetts State Police arrested 56 people during a three-day child exploitation operation named 'Operation Firewall.'
Authorities executed 34 search warrants and seized 229 electronic devices related to child enticement and abuse material.
Suspects, aged 18 to 75, faced charges including possession of child porn and attempted exploitation via undercover sting.

title: 5 ways to help fight food insecurity in the North Shore right now
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: SNAP benefits have been restored amid the ongoing government shutdown, affecting over one million in Massachusetts.
Beverly Bootstraps offers volunteer opportunities to organize food drives or create snack bags for children in need.
The Lynn Community Fridge provides 24/7 access to food, managed by the Lynn Family Resource Center.

title: SNAP fully funded, Healey says, as she urges residents to use benefits
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Gov. Maura Healey announces SNAP benefits in Massachusetts are fully funded and encourages residents to utilize them.
A federal judge temporarily blocked the Trump administration's directive to claw back SNAP benefits already issued.
Congress is close to an agreement that could end the shutdown, affecting SNAP funding and health insurance tax credits.

title: Falmouth to vote on turning historic golf course into solar farm
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Falmouth to vote on converting historic Cape Cod Country Club into a solar farm on November 17.
The project would install over 45,000 solar panels and conserve 137 acres of land for open space.
Articles debated include land donation, solar development lease, and efforts to remove the site from the solar overlay district.

title: Look inside Sheraton Boston’s whimsical new Goodnight Moon suite
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Sheraton Boston Hotel launched a Goodnight Moon suite available until February 28, 2026.
The suite, inspired by the 1947 children's book, features green walls, red carpet, and a glowing fireplace.
The hotel underwent a $100 million renovation and offers a package including four View Boston tickets and a $150 credit.

title: 2 kilos of fentanyl recovered after investigation into Southwest Corridor drug activity, police say
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Boston police recovered over two kilograms of fentanyl after executing search warrants in Dorchester, Mattapan, and Roxbury.
The investigation led to the arrests of five individuals allegedly involved in a fentanyl distribution network.
Authorities seized 32 rounds of ammunition, scales, drug packaging materials, and over $3,000 during the searches.

title: 2 MBTA operators sent to hospital after fallen wire causes fire near BC
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Two MBTA operators were hospitalized for smoke inhalation after a fallen wire sparked a fire on a Green Line trolley.
The incident occurred at Boston College Yard when 110 feet of catenary wire fell, causing hours-long service disruptions.
Repairs were completed in about an hour, but service resumed at 11:20 p.m. after shuttle buses replaced affected routes.

title: Abandoned manor overlooking the ocean gets new life in Nahant — thanks to Instagram
author: Regina Cole
bullets: The historic Howe Mansion in Nahant, built in 1880, underwent renovation and is now listed for $5.5 million.
Boston developer Volnay Capital restored the mansion after it faced abandonment and vandalism, reviving its Queen Anne architecture.
Interior designers retained historical elements while modernizing spaces, offering ocean views from nearly every room in the 10,820-square-foot home.
